1 ~ APPLIED CATALYSIS A: GENERAL ELSEVIER Applied Catalysis A: General 128 (1995) 171-207 Review Asymmetric synthesis by metal BINAP catalysts Susumu Akutagawa * Takasago International Corporation, 3-19-22, Takanawa, Minatoku, Tokyo 222, Japan Received 3 February 1995; accepted 12 April 1995 Abstract This article covers catalytic asymmetric syntheses effected by BINAP (R or S 2,2'-diphenylphos- phino- 1,1 '-binaphthyl) ligand. The atropisomeric ligand is outstanding in its extremely high enantio- selective recognition of hydrogen, when coordinated to rhodium or ruthenium metal. A unique chiral multiplication (asymmetric catalysis) derived from the isomerization of allylic amines to enamines by Rh-BINAP catalysis is reviewed from discovery to industrialization. The catalyst converted iso- prenoid allylic amine to citronellal enamine in perfect selectivities (99% yield and 98% enantiomer excess) and activity (TON > 400 000) that promised the commercial manufacturing of enantiom- erically pure terpene aldehydes. The industrial application of the highly sensitive and expensive Rh- BINAP catalyst for the production of 1500 t/y scale of chiral terpene compounds is introduced with some technical know how. A series of new ruthenium BINAP complexes was prepared and evaluated for asymmetric hydrogenation. Neutral Ru-BINAP dicarboxylato complexes catalyzed the hydrogen- ation of activated carbon-carbon double bonds enantioselectively. Prochiral unsaturated substrates including a-(acylamino)acrylic acids, allylic alcohols, a,/3-unsaturated carboxylic acids and cyclic enamides were easily reduced to give saturated products in quantitative yields with 90-99% enanti- omer excesses. Cationic Ru-BINAP complexes catalyzed the hydrogenation of functionalized ketones enantioselectively. Prochiral ketones beating hetero atom-containing functional groups at a, fl or 3' position were smoothly reduced affording corresponding alcohols in quantitative yields with high enantiomeric excesses. Industrial applications of these methodologies for pharmaceuticals and new materials are summarized. Keywords: Allylamine; Asymmetric synthesis; BINAP; Biodegradable polymers; fl-Lactam antibiotics; Chiral drug; Chiral ligand; Chiral terpene; Homogeneous catalysis; Hydrogenation; Isomerization; Isoprenoid amine; ( - )-Menthol; Rhodium; Ruthenium Contents 1. General introduction The importance of chirality in life science and new materials has been growing rapidly, which makes the manufacturing of chiral molecules one of the highlighted topics in modem fine chemical industry. Biologically active compounds, like phar- maceuticals, require one enantiomeric form. Wrong enantiomers are inactive or sometimes cause serious side effects. For the synthesis of chiral molecules, catalytic asymmetric synthesis should be superior to classical resolution or biological meth- ods if chemical and enantiomeric selectivities approach 100%. Asymmetric syn- thesis, under certain conditions, allows the production of enantiomerically pure compounds that have a wide range of applications in industry [ 1-4]. S. Transition metals have been used extensively as catalysts in organic synthesis. Usually the introduction of chiral ligands to metal complexes results in asymmetric catalysts. Although the first successful example was heterogeneous catalysis [5], recent achievements have been done mainly in the homogeneous area [6-9]. Homogeneous catalytic methods are advantageous in that the reaction is simple in operation, highly selective and applicable to a variety of substrates. Modern organ- ometallic chemistry has enabled the production of ideal catalysts that consist of the best matching of a metal with a chiral ligand. Various types of chiral ligands have been synthesized and evaluated aiming at higher enantiomeric selectivity [ 10,11]. However, a few have exemplified high enantiomeric excesses approaching 98- 100%. Some representative ligands that have furnished high ee's (> 90%) are illustrated in Fig. 1. This article concerns the homogeneous asymmetric reactions catalyzed by BINAP ( 1 ) coordinated metal complexes principally [ 12-14]. A biphenyl oriented atropisomeric ligand 2 [ 15-17] showed similar reactivity as BINAP. Initially the majority of researches on homogeneous metal catalysis pursued the hydrogenations of a-(acylamino)acrylic acid for the synthesis of a-amino acids (Eq. 1) [ 18-20]. A highly sophisticated chelate ligand 4, where both phosphorus atoms are chiral, was developed by Monsanto Co. and used in the commercial production of /-DOPA, a drug for Parkinsonian disease [22]. Ligands 5 (ferrocene based) and 6 ( ( - )-proline oriented) have shown high enantiomeric excesses in a series of 174 S. Akutagawa / Applied Catalysis A." Ligands possessing C2 symmetry, 7 [ 25 ] and 8 [ 26 ], are noteworthy in that they give excellent catalytic activities in asymmetric hydrogenation of carbon to nitrogen double bonds. A unique chiral multiplication (asymmetric catalysis) was first observed by an enantioselective hydrogen migration of prochiral allylamine to enamine (Eq. 2) [27]. (2) When the reaction was catalyzed by a cationic rhodium complex of BINAP, surprisingly high chemical and enantiomeric selectivities, of 99% and 98%, respec- tively, were obtained [28 ]. The process has exemplified the world's largest asym- metric synthesis of (-)-menthol by homogeneous catalysis [29]. This article summarizes the discovery of the asymmetric isomerization and improvements of the catalyst system with the emphasis on process development. The versatility of Ru-BINAP complexes has been revealed as asymmetric hydro- genation catalysts for a series of unsaturated substrates (Eq. 3). Prochiral alkene substrates including a-(acylamino) acrylic acids (X = CO2H, Y = NHAc), allylic alcohols (X = H or alkyl, Y = C-OH), a,/3-unsaturated carboxylic acids (X = H, Y=CO2H) and enamides (X=H or alkyl, Y=NHAc) are smoothly reduced affording the corresponding saturated compounds in extremely high enantiomer excesses (90-99%) [30]. We first introduced the complex 9 for the asymmetric isomerization of allylic amine to enamine (Eq. 2) [36], then developed the cati- onic rhodium bis BINAP complex (11) for the industrial operation [37]. We prepared the/x-chloro Ru-BINAP complex (12), and used it as a catalyst for the hydrogenation of carbonyl substrates (Eq. 4) [38]. Noyori and Takaya converted 12 to the Ru-BINAP dicarboxylato complex (13) by the ligand exchange reaction in a binary phase [ 39]. This complex showed extremely high selectivities in the hydrogenation of a variety of carbon to carbon double bonds (Eq. 3). They also prepared the bromine-containing complex (14), in a polymeric form, by the reaction of 13 with 2 mol of hydrogen bromide [40]. Takaya synthesized a series of arene coordinated complexes (15) by the reaction of [RuC12(arene)] and BINAP in DMF at 100 following the anion exchange by potassium iodide [41 ]. Those Ru-BINAP complexes bearing a halogen anion (14, 15) have revealed excellent catalytic activities for the hydrogenation of carbonyl substrates as depicted in Eq. 4. 3. Asymmetric isomerization 3.1. Introduction Although simple allylamine was isomerized to enamine by various metal cata- lysts, y,y'-disubstituted homologues (R ~ H in Eq. 2) were not susceptible to the catalysts or showed only low reactivity [27 ]. Surprisingly, we found that a Co (I)- DIOP (3) complex catalyzed the isomerization of N,N-diethyl-geranyl (16) and neryl amine (17) to optically active citronellal (E)-enamine (18) in 35% ee (Eq. 5) [42]. ~NEt2 +NEt2 Catalyst ~NEt2+ ~v2"~NEt2 16 ~17 ~ 18 /'~ 19 (5) Optically active citronellal, which can be quantitatively obtained from 18, is a useful intermediate for the synthesis of many optically active natural terpenes. Thus the new asymmetric isomerization, though the enantiomeric excess was not suffi- cient, opened the door to the synthesis of chiral terpene compounds. Great improve- ments in the chemical and enantiomerical selectivities in Eq. 5 (up to 99% yield for 18 in 98% ee) were achieved by employing 9 as a catalyst [43]. Further studies in Rh (I)-BINAP species led to the discovery of the thermally stable complex ( 11 ) providing the high tumover number of 400 000 (TON, enamine moles produced by one mole of catalyst during 18 h) without impairing any selectivities [44]. The asymmetric isomerization of open chain dialkyl allylamines by Ru-BINAP has become a typical example, where the relationship between substrate and catalyst S. Almost all trials in applying the catalysis for another allylic system were unsuccessful, suggesting that the critical point of the reaction be brought from the coordination of the allylic nitrogen atom to rhodium metal. 3.2. Isomerization of isoprenoid amine There are practical merits in choosing allylamines 16 and 17 as substrates for the enantioselective isomerization: ( 1 ) Enantiomerically pure citronellal, which is an important starting material for optically active terpenoids, can be obtained; (2) Both trans and cis allylamines can be prepared in excellent yields from myrcene (20) [45] or isoprene [46,47], respectively (Eq. 6 and Eq. 7). HNEt2 / LiNEt2 [% [.NEt2 II 17 (7) Migrations of multi-substituted inner double bonds of 16 or 17, shown in Eq. 5, were effected by various metal catalysts (Table 1 ). The catalytic activity and the reaction selectivity varied dramatically depending on the catalyst employed. Titanium catalysts isomerized double bonds at 2 and 6 together, affording a conjugated dienamine (19) selectively. Low valent cobalt complexes isomerized 16 to 18 ( 81-85 % ) accompanying 19 ( 15-19% ). In contrast to these, cationic rhodium(I) complexes coordinated with monodentate or bidentate phosphines isomerized 16 and 17 to 18 selectively without the formation of 19 [48]. Results of the asymmetric isomerization, shown in Table 2, were obtained by cobalt and rhodium complexes coupled with several types of chiral ligands. We 178 S. However, the migration of the double bond 6 was also caused to give a considerable amount of 19. Tani modified DIOP to a tris-alkyl type diphosphine, CyDIOP [ = 2,3-O-isopropylidene-2,3-dihydroxy- 1,4-bis (dicy- clohexylphosphino) butane]; that exhibited a considerable gain in enantioselectiv- ity compared to its prototype (from 35% to 77%). The ligand BINAP, when coordinated with rhodium metal, showed excellent enantioselectivity, chemoselec- tivity and catalytic activity for the isomerization. In contrast, BINAP could not attain high selectivities with cobalt metal. A research group of Hoffman La Roche reported similar results by using BIPHEMP (2) [ 15]. These characteristics of BINAP and BIPHEMP-based catalysts seem to be brought about by their tris-aryl structures where all substituents on both phosphorus atoms are aromatic groups. In the isomerization, one favorable feature is the desirable stereochemical cor- relation between substrate geometries, product configurations and BINAP chirality, as shown in Scheme 2. Since BINAP enantiomers and both (E)-and ( Z)-allylamine substrates are easily obtainable, this stereochemical relationship provides the eco- nomical advantages in the option of taking the starting material either from natural resources or petroleum. Akutagawa /Applied Catalysis A: General 128 (1995) 171-207 4. Asymmetric hydrogenation by Ru-BINAP 4.1. Introduction Asymmetric hydrogenation of unsaturated substrates is progressing rapidly by using various homogeneous metal catalysts. Of the chiral catalysts, ruthenium complexes of BINAP have exemplified excellent activities and enantioselectivities in asymmetric hydrogenations of alkenes and ketones. As BINAP ligand has been used widely coupled with various transition metals such as rhodium and iridium, this chapter covers also those relating subjects for references. Asymmetric hydrogenation implementing the Ru-BINAP catalyst is described as follows: (1) Scope of the reaction; Various prochiral carbon-carbon double bonds can give saturated chiral compounds, while prochiral carbonyl groups give chiral secondary alcohols. Neither isolated double bonds nor simple ketones can undergo this reaction. (2) Reaction selectivity; Almost quantitative chemoselec- tivity and above 90% enantioselectivity are obtainable. (3) Catalyst activity; Reac- tions can be carried out smoothly under moderate conditions (5-50 kg/cm2 hydrogen pressure, ambient to 100 reaction temperature), using a very high catalyst/substrate molar ratio 1 / 10 000. The following procedures are representative for the Ru-BINAP catalyzed asym- metric hydrogenations: Reactions were carried out in stainless-steel autoclaves at 20-100 using usually methanol as a solvent, under a hydrogen pressure of 5- 100 kg/cm2. After the reaction, the ruthenium complex was precipitated by adding pentane and removed by filtration through Celite. The whole mixture was concen- trated and isolated by distillation or crystallization. Usually HPLC analysis (chiral column) was applied for the determination of enantiomeric excesses. 4.2. Hydrogenations of diketones satisfactorily discriminate the chelate mechanism of Ru-BINAP catalysis; namely the hydrogenation of 2,4-pentandione gave anti 2,4-pentandiol selectively, while 2,5-hexandione afforded solely 5-hydroxy-2-hex- anone. In 1,3-diketones, the first step, hydrogenation, is effected by the neighboring carbonyl and the second step is brought about by the assistance of the hydroxy giving anti 1,3-glycol (Eq. 34). However, the hydrogenation of 1,4-diketones gives keto-alcohols, the second carbonyl remains intact (Eq. 35). It is plausible that the coordination power of the remote hydroxy in 5-hydroxy-2-hexanone is not sufficient to affect the hydrogenation of the carbonyl at the 3' position. Therefore, in Ru-BINAP catalysis, we assume the effect of carbonyl is more powerful than that of the hydroxy group. For industrial applications, the consumption of chiral auxiliaries should be minimum by thoroughly improving TON. It is also necessary to complete the synthetic scheme before (substrate 198 S. Following items are successful examples of how industry has made use of metal BINAP catalysts economically [ 142,143 ]. 6.1. (-)-menthol Since 1983 we have been successfully producing (-)-menthol and related enantiomerically pure terpene compounds on a commercial basis (ca. 1500 t/year) using the asymmetric isomerization introduced in Section 3 [ 144]. We have estab- lished the catalyst recycle system as follows: After the isomerization is completed, all reactants (THF, enamine and catalyst) are subjected to distillation under reduced pressure (initially 400 Torr, finally 2 Torr) to recover the solvent and the product. The active complex (11) can be precipitated and recovered (ca. 98%) from the distillation residue by the addition of n-heptane. Consequently the next batch requires only a small portion (ca. 2%) of the fresh catalyst. It is also possible to recover key components (rhodium metal and BINAP) from the n-heptane solution, thus making the total balance of precious materials above 99.8%. The improvement of the TON is summarized in Table 10. Initially, the catalyst decomposition ratio was 10% per batch, but it has become 2% (or less) owing to the total quality control [ 29]. After the isomerization the production of ( - )-menthol is carried out according to Scheme 7. The ZnBr2-catalyzed cyclization of citro- nellal, an intra-molecular ene reaction, runs stereo-specifically affording solely equatorial (-)-isopulegol. Thus 500 drugs are possible candidates for 'Racemate Switch'. 6.2.1. ~-Lactam antibiotics Many modifications of carbapenem and penem molecules have been claimed as potential candidates for the next coming generation of antibiotics. Consequently the demand for the key intermediate, 4-acetoxyazetidin-2-one (60), is increasing for the practical manufacturing of these complex molecules (Figs. 7 and 7). According to Scheme 8 we launched the commercial production of 60 on a 50 tons scale in 1992. There are two key technologies in the process, one of which used the Ru-BINAP catalyst to produce two adjacent asymmetric centers in the desirable configuration [83]. Its starting material, methyl 2-benzoylaminomethyl- 3-keto-butanoate, is conveniently obtainable from commodity chemicals by usual organic syntheses. The other is a unique acetoxylation of the/3-1actam ring by peracetic acid, which is promoted by ruthenium metal catalysts. The stereochemical mode of the reaction is sufficient for the desired relative configuration of 60 [ 145-147]. We assume the mechanism to be a nucleophilic addition of acetic acid to an acyl iminium ion intermediate (61), which in turn formed by the attack of the oxo-ruthenium com- plex to the highly strained/3-1actam ring (Scheme 9). 6.2.2. o~-Tocopherol side chain Synthetic vitamin E is being produced and marketed in 10 000 tons annually as a racemate mixture. Natural vitamin E contains two chiral moieties, chromanic part and C- 15 side chain. Biodegradable polymers Nowadays, we should pay considerable attention toward global environmental and ecological problems. New biodegradable polymers for disposal use might be an answer from chemical industry. The most famous biodegradable material is poly-3 (R)-hydroxybutyrate accumulated by microbes. The Ru-BINAP catalysis is capable to offer access to biodegradable polymers by chemical pathways. 202 S. Akutagawa / Applied Catalysis A: General 128 (1995) 171-207 64 65 Scheme 11. Usually the condensation of methyl 3(R)-hydroxybutyrate to high molecular weight polymers was extremely difficult because of the unstable secondary hydroxy moiety. One successful protection of the fragile hydroxy group was exemplified in the synthesis of 7-membered ether lactone (64, Scheme 11 ) prepared by the reac- tion of ethylene oxide with methyl 3(R)-hydroxybutyrate. New polymers (65) with high qualities were prepared by the ring-opening polymerization of the lactone. However, the polymer did not show any significant biodegradation. We synthesized poly (urethane-ester) comprising a poly-3 ( R ) -hydroxybutyrate segment, by which a clue for the relationship between chemical structure and biodegradability was provided. First a telechelic oligomer (66, Scheme 12) was synthesized by the condensation of a diol with an appropriate equivalent (3-5) of methyl 3 (R) -hydroxybutyrate. Then the polymer (67) was obtained by the addition polymerization of 66 with hexamethylene diisocyanate. When the polymer was exposed to a cell culture containing Pseudomonas lemoignei, found in soil, for 3 weeks, a distinct weight loss of 40% was observed [ 148]. Based on these observations we attained a hypothesis that a segment consisting of at least three consecutive units of 3 (R)-hydroxybutyrate is indispensable for providing the polymer with significant biodegradation capability. The asymmetric hydrogenation of diketene by modified Ru-BINAP catalysts (see Eq. 29 in Section 4.2.5) has opened a way to synthetic poly-3(R)-hydrox- ybutyrate (Scheme 13). We are ready to produce economical and controlled degradable polymers with high qualities by the scheme: First, pyrolysis of acetic acid to diketene; second, the asymmetric hydrogenation of diketene to the optically active/3-1actone (32); and third, ring opening polymerization. The analysis of the enantiomeric excess of the hydrolyzed polymer showed that the fission of/3-1actone occurred with retention of chirality. Co-polymerizations of the lactone with gly- colide and lactide gave high quality polymers, 68 and 69 respectively. 7. A strong demand for the cost reduction of ( - )-menthol summoned the idea of the isomer- ization. The first synthesis of BINAP was just in time providing all requisites. In addition, it is noteworthy that the progress of BINAP chemistry has been accom- plished by the collaboration of academia and industry. Presently remaining problems in asymmetric methodologies are hydrogenations of carbon-nitrogen double bonds and hydrocarboxylation. We must pay much effort to the development of asymmetric carbon to carbon bond forming catalysis. The introduction of chirality in advanced, or multi-functional materials is less popular compared to the field of life science. In the future, the chirality will play an important role in the following new materials and devices: Ferroelectric liquid crystals are promising in flat displays and optical switches. Several new models of projection type TV and printing machines are going to adapt shutter arrays com- posed of ferroelectric liquid crystals. Organic non-linear optics with second har- monic generation might cause considerable progress in new devices for computing and telecommunications. Biodegradable and chiral nematic liquid crystalline pol- ymers are growing topics in polymers and new functionalities are expected. Homo- geneous metal catalysis, in accord with heterogeneous system [ 149-151] and biological methods [152,153], will promote the production of those important chiral molecules. References [ 1] H.B. APCATA 95000976 0926-860X(95)00097-6 10.1016/0926-860X(95)00097-6 Review Asymmetric synthesis by metal BINAP catalysts Susumu Akutagawa â Takasago International Corporation, 3-19-22, Takanawa, Minatoku, Tokyo 222, Japan â Corresponding author. Tel. (+81-3) 34421211, Fax. (+81-3) 34421732. This article covers catalytic asymmetric syntheses effected by BINAP (R or S 2,2â²-diphenylphosphino-1,1â²-binaphthyl) ligand. The atropisomeric ligand is outstanding in its extremely high enantioselective recognition of hydrogen, when coordinated to rhodium or ruthenium metal. A unique chiral multiplication (asymmetric catalysis) derived from the isomerization of allylic amines to enamines by Rh-BINAP catalysis is reviewed from discovery to industrialization. The catalyst converted isoprenoid allylic amine to citronellal enamine in perfect selectivities (99% yield and 98% enantiomer excess) and activity (TON > 400 000) that promised the commercial manufacturing of enantiomerically pure terpene aldehydes. The industrial application of the highly sensitive and expensive Rh-BINAP catalyst for the production of 1500 t/y scale of chiral terpene compounds is introduced with some technical know how. A series of new ruthenium BINAP complexes was prepared and evaluated for asymmetric hydrogenation. Neutral Ru-BINAP dicarboxylato complexes catalyzed the hydrogenation of activated carbon-carbon double bonds enantioselectively. Prochiral unsaturated substrates including Î±-(acylamino)acrylic acids, allylic alcohols, Î±,Î²-unsaturated carboxylic acids and cyclic enamides were easily reduced to give saturated products in quantitative yields with 90â99% enantiomer excesses. Cationic Ru-BINAP complexes catalyzed the hydrogenation of functionalized ketones enantioselectively. Prochiral ketones bearing hetero atom-containing functional groups at Î±,Î² or Î³ position were smoothly reduced affording corresponding alcohols in quantitative yields with high enantiomeric excesses. Industrial applications of these methodologies for pharmaceuticals and new materials are summarized. coredata.dc:description: This article covers catalytic asymmetric syntheses effected by BINAP (R or S 2,2â²-diphenylphosphino-1,1â²-binaphthyl) ligand. The atropisomeric ligand is outstanding in its extremely high enantioselective recognition of hydrogen, when coordinated to rhodium or ruthenium metal. A unique chiral multiplication (asymmetric catalysis) derived from the isomerization of allylic amines to enamines by Rh-BINAP catalysis is reviewed from discovery to industrialization. The catalyst converted isoprenoid allylic amine to citronellal enamine in perfect selectivities (99% yield and 98% enantiomer excess) and activity (TON > 400 000) that promised the commercial manufacturing of enantiomerically pure terpene aldehydes. The industrial application of the highly sensitive and expensive Rh-BINAP catalyst for the production of 1500 t/y scale of chiral terpene compounds is introduced with some technical know how. A series of new ruthenium BINAP complexes was prepared and evaluated for asymmetric hydrogenation. Neutral Ru-BINAP dicarboxylato complexes catalyzed the hydrogenation of activated carbon-carbon double bonds enantioselectively. Prochiral unsaturated substrates including Î±-(acylamino)acrylic acids, allylic alcohols, Î±,Î²-unsaturated carboxylic acids and cyclic enamides were easily reduced to give saturated products in quantitative yields with 90â99% enantiomer excesses. Cationic Ru-BINAP complexes catalyzed the hydrogenation of functionalized ketones enantioselectively. Prochiral ketones bearing hetero atom-containing functional groups at Î±,Î² or Î³ position were smoothly reduced affording corresponding alcohols in quantitative yields with high enantiomeric excesses. Industrial applications of these methodologies for pharmaceuticals and new materials are summarized.
coredata.dc:title: Asymmetric synthesis by metal BINAP catalysts
